timeline.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: This does more than just check, it also performs the cleanup. Perhaps rename to cleanupReplicaIfRequired. Or maybe better move the if (replicationMode == FULL_OVERWRITE) { up to where it was before and then call this method cleanupReplica as it only applies to that mode.
timeline.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't it be better to move this to line 448? There's no need to create a client unless we get that far.
timeline.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Should we log e here too so we know why?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText:
should't we just throw the exception and stop?
We haven't deleted the existing one so writing again will probably fail anyway.
replies.author: patduin

timeline.bodyText: How is this different to dropTable now? If we're always going to remove the params in that method then I'm not sure we need this one anymore?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: Its technically no different, but it gets the table object and passes that into the dropTable method. I added the dropTable method and made it take in a table object because otherwise when dropTableAndData is called it would get the table object, delete partition info, then call dropTable which will get the table object again and then drop it. So by doing it this way it reduces the number of times that client.getTable is called.
replies.author: JayGreeeen

timeline.bodyText: Are we OK with not doing the whole partition iterator trick here? I guess for most of this type of table they're generally not very big so it's unlikely this will return tens of thousands of partitions and run out of memory like we've had in other parts of the code so it's probably fine.
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText:
Do you mean the hcommon PartitionIterator trick? b/c if so then it does use that in the getPartitionLocations method at the bottom of the class.
PartitionIterator partitionIterator = new PartitionIterator(client, table, BATCH_SIZE);
replies.author: JayGreeeen

timeline.author: massdosage
massdosage
massdosage

replies.bodyText: Yes this is not useful to log and might even be confusing.
replies.author: patduin

timeline.bodyText: At the moment this will stop if one of the partitions couldn't be dropped. Wouldn't it be better to put the try/catch around line 124 so it can try each location? And then basically do an AND on the booleans returned so if any one is false then the method returns false.
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText:
I think we should log on line 124 before doing the delete which location we're trying to delete and then let the exception bubble up. Why try all of them if 1 fails and 99 succeeds shouldn't we stop the replication?
This feature is about deleting existing table/data + replication if one part of this fails the whole thing should fail?
replies.author: patduin

replies.bodyText: OK, as long as the approach is consistent, I'm fine with it being "as soon as anything goes wrong, ABORT AND FAIL!"
replies.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Then this message can log the actual partition location which will be more meaningful (and also log the exception)
timeline.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need this?
timeline.author: massdosage

timeline.bodyText: Ah OK, so we do use the iterator but we then add them all to a list so this could still OOM. I think it's alright to do this for now but the "proper" way would be to use the iterator, not an intermediate collection.
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: let's fix this please, we've hit this in the past, it's better to make this resistant now since we're testing it actively and actually have it fresh in our heads.
replies.author: patduin

timeline.bodyText:
Log the exception.
Also, should we swallow all these exceptions with warnings or should we throw them and fail the replication?
timeline.author: massdosage

replies.bodyText: I don't mind. It technically wont affect the replication, but you could end up with a lot of orphaned data which wont be cleaned up.
replies.author: JayGreeeen

replies.bodyText: I think all exceptions in this class except ones we can recover from should be thrown and stop the replication. Logging them serves little purpose, no one is going to look through the log if the end replication reports OK. If the purpose is alerting the user to manually clean up, best to just fail. If this becomes unfeasible e.g. lots of failures we can build retry mechanics etc.. but out of scope now.
replies.author: patduin

timeline.bodyText: You can do this on line 39
timeline.author: massdosage
